Award.AwardTitle: II-EN: Computational Enhancement of Analytical Metagenomics Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are both harmful and benign bacteria and viruses all around us. Scientists use a technique called metagenomics to characterize these organisms by extracting DNA from a sample, and deciphering the genetic code of all of the DNA sequences. The scientific approach typified by metagenomics is to generate data and rely on large, fast, computers to solve complex problems. The Computational Enhancement of Analytical Metagenomics Systems award supports this work with computational infrastructure and training.

Intellectual Merit: The team working on this project are world-leaders in the development of tools and analyses for metagenomics data. The computational infrastructure enabled by this award continues their leadership in this area for the coming decade. The computing infrastructure is also used by researchers at both San Diego State and other Universities in California, the United States, and around the world. The infrastructure enables the researchers to tackle really difficult problems that they couldn't approach before. An ~500 core computer cluster including machines with lots of memory and disk storage space allows the scientists to run their massive computations required to analyze this data to protect our nation, develop new therapeutics and understand our world.

Broader Impacts: This proposal directly supports an NSF Transforming Undergraduate Education in Science program that teaches genomics and metagenomics to undergraduate students at San Diego State University, an Hispanic-Serving Institution. Over the last six years SDSU has improved the graduation rate of all students by providing access to cutting edge research equipment like that proposed here.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of this project was the development and deployment of a 640 processor, 5120 core compute cluster and 192 TB hard drive storage system at San Diego State University. This cluster is primarily used by scientists working at the interface of Computer Science and Biology, using bioinformatics tools to analyze biological data.

The team using this cluster develop tools to explore microbes in the different environments, in particular those affecting the health of the oceans including coral reefs and kelp forests, and how those microbes affect human health. We have 120 scientists using the cluster, and have generated 120 TB of raw data that we are analyzing (this is approximately equivilent to 30,000 DVDs of data).

By analyzing this data, we found a novel virus that infects bacteria and is present in approximately half the people in the world. We are investigating this virus to identify what it does in the human intesting. We developed and tested important new theories about the relationships between viruses and bacteria using this computational infrastructure. This theory predicts that when bacteria become very abundant it is more important for the viruses to hide inside the bacteria than remain outside.

We also enabled scientists around the US and the world to analyze their data. Our colleagues were given access and training to use these computational tools, ensuring that our students remain at the forefront of computer science. By building websites where people can submit data for analysis on our cluster, we enable scientists with no training in high-throughput computing to access the latest tools for biological data analysis. This collaborative approach ensures that science, especially that around the role of microbes in the environment, progresses.
